text: [Music]
your brain is beautiful and complex
built to keep you safe and guide you
through life its main job is to protect
you but when you go through trauma that
protection can go into overdrive it's
like bodyguards constantly hitting the
emergency button even when there's no
real threat trauma shifts your brain
into survival mode reshaping how you
think feel and act sometimes long after
the event has passed it doesn't matter
what type of trauma you've been through
whether it's physical emotional or
psychological stemming from your
childhood or adult life all forms of
trauma impact the brain in profound ways
if you're curious about the different
types of trauma check out our previous
video where we break them down in more
detail if you've experienced trauma
navigating life afterward can feel
overwhelming and you might even find
that you're being a little too hard on
yourself that's why we created this
video to explore how trauma affects your
brain understanding the neuros pychology
of trauma can provide valuable insights
to help you and other survivors move
forward with compassion and strength
tuning into
senses were you startled by a sudden
sound even though it seemed like no one
else in the room reacted according to an
article in current opinion in
neurobiology ology trauma can affect how
you process sensory information you may
become extra sensitive to sensory inputs
things like sounds sights or touch
specifically a traumatic experience can
change the structure of white matter a
bundle of nerve fibers and gray matter a
group of nerve cell bodies these changes
happen in your sensory cortex a part of
the brain that is responsible for
processing sensory signals from the
outside world this is the brain's way of
staying on high alert for any possible
danger for example a normal sound like a
door creaking or a phone vibrating might
set off a stress response even if there
is no real threat and over time
constantly being on edge like this can
become so exhausting it can make you
feel anxious uncomfortable and unsafe in
everyday situations
the body's Whispers traumatic events can
also impact how you recognize what's
happening in your body like being hungry
or thirsty normally your brain helps you
pick up on these physical signals and
lets you know when it's time to eat
drink or rest helping you stay balanced
and take care of yourself this process
is called
interoception but trauma can cause the
brain to ignore or misread these cues
interoception educator Kelly states that
trauma survivors may have trouble
noticing when they're hungry exhausted
or stressed has this ever happened to
you not realizing that you're hungry or
thirsty until your hand start shaking
and your energy gets depleted not
realizing you have to go to the bathroom
until it's almost too late this
confusion about your physical needs can
make it even more difficult to stay on
top of your self-care something that's
incredibly important for healing from
your TR
reward tokens maybe you've noticed that
your hobbies or interests have become
unexciting after going through something
traumatic one 2015 study points out that
for many survivors the stress from
trauma dulls the brain's response to
rewarding
experiences when you're stressed or
traumatized your brain's fear Center the
amydala becomes overactive while the
part that helps you regulate emotions
the prefrontal cortex doesn't really
work as well as before this imbalance
affects the production of dopamine the
brains feel good chemical as a result
you stop getting the same rewards from
the things you used to enjoy this is
called anhedonia the inability to
experience joy and pleasure as you
continue to struggle with anonia
everything starts feeling flat or
unexciting leaving you disconnected from
those positive feelings the chasing
Slumber sleep can be a real struggle for
people who have experienced trauma when
you sleep your brain produces electrical
signals called brain waves some of which
are linked to stress and agitation after
trauma the brain's stress centers like
the amydala that we mentioned earlier
become more active triggering higher
levels of these stress related brain
waves this affects your brain's ability
to get the Deep restorative rest it
needs you might find yourself waking up
frequently during the night or
struggling to fall asleep at all a study
published in the journal sleep suggests
your brain can also have trouble
entering the deeper stages of sleep like
R which are crucial for emotional
healing and balance and on top of all
that Vivid nightmares might make you
want to avoid sleep altogether a study
that examined sleep disturbances in
people with PTSD also mentions sleep
paralysis occurring as a result of
trauma have you ever experienced one
share your experiences in the comments
if you feel
comfortable
rewiring the good news is that the brain
is capable of healing especially with
the right tools and support
trauma-informed therapies like EMDR eye
movement desensitization and through
processing and CPT cognitive processing
therapy are specifically designed to
help rewire the brain and Support
Recovery alongside these therapies
mindfulness practices and healthy social
support play a vital role in healing if
you're looking to take steps towards
recovery here are a few practical
actions you can try establish a routine
trauma can make everything feel
unpredictable creating a daily routine
can bring stability and a sense of
control Journal your emotions writing
down your thoughts and feelings can help
you process your experiences and make
sense of difficult emotions limit
triggers identify situations or things
that bring up trauma related stress and
take small steps to reduce your exposure
to these
triggers celebrate small winds healing
is a journey so take time to acknowledge
and celebrate even the smallest steps
forward to stay motivated and connected
to your progress
engage in Creative Outlets art music or
other creative activities can help you
express what words may not be able to
capture do you relate to any of the
signs we've talked about I sure did if
you do please remember that what you're
experiencing is completely normal trauma
takes a toll on your brain and it's not
your fault but just as it got wired to
experience these symptoms it can get
rewired again it is 100% % possible for
you to one day feel calm safe and happy
thanks so much for watching and for
being here take care
